event_details.name: WSM: Epidemic - 04-2025 - Dengue Fever Outbreak

reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
The Ministry of Health officially declared a dengue fever outbreak in Samoa on 17 April 2025 (Source: Declaration of Dengue Fever Outbreak for Samoa – Government of Samoa), following a significant increase in the number of suspected and confirmed cases, particularly on Upolu Island. As of the latest epidemiological week ending 14 July 2025, Samoa has recorded 331 new laboratory-confirmed cases of dengue fever, according to the most recent situation report issued on 14 July 2025.

Key Highlights
•	Since January 2025, a total of 1,276 dengue lab-confirmed cases have been recorded
•	The cumulative total of 1,276 cases reflects an incidence rate of 620.7 cases per 100,000 population
•	The most affected age group is under 20 years old (87%)
•	One dengue-related death has been recorded to date
•	81% of cases were reported from Upolu Island, with 55% male and 45% female
•	10% of cases were hospitalized at TTMH, and 76% of those have been discharged
•	The majority of cases are distributed across the Apia Urban Area (AUA) and North West of Upolu (NWU)
reports.summary: WSM: Epidemic - 07-2025 - Dengue Fever Outbreak
reports.description:
The majority of cases (81%) are from Upolu Island, with 55% male and 45% female. Most cases are distributed across the Apia Urban Area and North West of Upolu regions, with individuals under 20 years old (87%) being the most affected. 10% of cases required hospitalisation, and of these admissions, 76% have been discharged. Of the 20 cases with confirmed serotypes, 85% are DENV-1 and 15% are DENV-2. 
The Ministry of Health continues collaboration across sectors through a whole-of-government approach via the Integrated Vector Control Committee. Current response efforts are focused on source reduction and environmental sanitation measures, ongoing risk communication on dengue preventative measures on all media outlets while urging the public to wear long-sleeved clothing to minimize risk of infection, use mosquito nets and repellents, remain vigilant for severe symptoms and to seek medical attention immediately when necessary. The red alert for DENV-1 and DENV-2 is maintained.
Climate change is promoting the spread of dengue fever in small South Pacific countries by increasing temperatures, accelerating the life cycle of vector mosquitoes and accelerating virus transmission. Increased rainfall and humidity are creating more breeding sites, while flooding and rising sea levels are increasing the conditions conducive to their proliferation. Growing urbanization and internal migration are increasing the risks, as are longer transmission seasons due to milder winters.
reports.title: Dengue Fever Outbreak
reports.actions_others: Ministry of Health and the Government have meeting to discuss the outbreak and have plans have its partners to involve in making plans on response.
reports.other_sources: SITREP from the Ministry of Health

actions_taken.summary:
Summary/ Situation

Since 26 June, heavy monsoon rains have triggered flash floods, landslides, and house collapses across Pakistan, causing widespread devastation. The worst-affected areas include Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), Punjab, Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK), Sindh, and Balochistan. As of 23 July, 252 people have lost their lives, 611 have been injured, and nearly 1006 houses have been partially/ completely destroyed. Critical infrastructure such as roads and a major bridge have been damaged, while approximately 328 livestock have perished. In response, the National and Provincial Disaster Management Authorities (NDMA and PDMAs) have activated Emergency Operations Centers (EOCs) in all provinces. Technical teams have been deployed to assess damage and guide immediate relief efforts. Government agencies are providing emergency support through camps, mobile health units, and damage assessments, with regular daily reports guiding operations. To date, over 3398 relief items have been distributed across affected provinces, ensuring life-saving support while planning for continued response and recovery. 
Simultaneously, the Pakistan Red Crescent Society (PRCS), supported by the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), has mobilized its national and provincial branches. PRCS is preparing to activate its Simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) for Riverine Floods, particularly in anticipation of high flood levels in the Kabul River as forecasted by the Pakistan Meteorological Department. All provincial branches have activated Operations Rooms and Emergency Operations Centers functioning 24/7, with local volunteers engaged in assessments and relief distribution. PRCS headquarters is holding daily emergency coordination meetings and has dispatched two ambulances to support the setup of Mobile Health Units in Upper Dir and Swat. Coordination with government stakeholders remains ongoing to enhance the effectiveness of the response. IFRC’s Country Delegation in Pakistan and Asia Pacific Regional Office (APRO) continue to monitor the situation closely, ensuring technical support and readiness for scaled-up operations as needed.

Action taken till date:

1. Damage/Needs Assessment All provincial branches are submitting regular, daily assessment reports to monitor the evolving situation on the ground. 

2. Health & First Aid Support: The PRCS National Headquarters has dispatched two ambulances to the Provincial Branch to support the development of Mobile Health Units in Upper Dir and Swat Districts.

3. Anticipatory Actions Based on the Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) if the forecast predicts a very high flood level on the Kabul River above 200 cusec water, PRCS will activate its Simplified Early Action Protocol, which includes: Multipurpose Cash Assistance: 14,820 individuals (2,470 households) will receive unconditional cash grants to support timely evacuation and protect livelihoods. Early Warning Dissemination: Flood alerts will be shared with 37,315 people through community volunteers, SMS, megaphones, and public announcements. 

4. Response Actions Under the directive of the Joint Director Operations (NHQ) : All provincial branches have activated Operations Rooms, and are coordinating with external stakeholders and monitoring the situation closely. Daily emergency meetings are being held at NHQ to review developments and response strategies. Emergency Control Rooms have been set up at both National Headquarters and branch levels from 26th June, with assigned staff and volunteer duty rosters. Emergency vehicles are on standby for rapid deployment across all PRCS levels. A multi-agency emergency operations meeting was held at PRCS National Headquarters, attended by: Partner national societies IFRC PRCS Response Team Other relevant departments 

5. PRCS Response to Nullah Lai, Katarian, and Gawalmandi Situations Water levels: 23 feet at Gawalmandi 22 feet at Katarian (close to the critical 24 feet threshold) PRCS has deployed Emergency Response Teams , including trained volunteers and first aiders , to these locations in Rawalpindi . The situation remains under control , with no major damages or evacuations reported. 

6. Branch-Level Coordination Framework To ensure an organized and efficient response: All branches have activated Emergency Operations Centers (EOCs) operating 24/7 . Regular staff meetings are being held to assign roles and strategize response actions. Specialized teams have been formed, including: Logistics personnel First aid responders BDRTs and CDRTs Real-time communication is maintained via dedicated WhatsApp groups , ensuring daily updates with National Headquarters . Local volunteers are engaged in assessments and relief efforts, enhancing community-level response.

reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: The Ministry of Health is working on the SitREP
reports.summary: GMB: Epidemic - 07-2025 - Outbreak of Mpox in The Gambia
reports.description:
"On July 10, 2025, a 26-year-old female, residing in Kunkujang Keitaya, Kombo North District, in the Western One Health Region, reported to Faji-kunda Major Health Centre with skin lesions. 
From her clinical records, her symptoms began with rashes on July 8, 2025 followed by mucosal lesions affecting the skin, genital and oral regions, accompanied by fatigue, muscle pain, soft tissue edema (swelling) in the genital area, back pain, headache, and sore throat. 
Localized and generalized enlargement of lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) were other symptoms noticed upon examination at the health centre." Ministry of Health The Gambia

https://www.facebook.com/share/p/194WtKqLme/
reports.title: Outbreak of Mpox in The Gambia
reports.actions_others:
The Ministry of Health of The Gambia has activated the National Public Health Emergency Operations Centre (PHEOC) and established the Incident Management System (IMS) for coordinated response, with daily stakeholder meetings and updates.

A comprehensive response plan guides outbreak containment efforts, including Deployment of Rapid Response Teams (RRTs), Identification of isolation units, Stockpiling of medical supplies, and Capacity building in laboratory, surveillance, and case management.

Confirmed and suspected cases are isolated and receiving appropriate treatment under medical supervision.

Surveillance has been intensified at all levels. Health facility staff and community signal detectors are trained and equipped to detect and report suspected cases. Refresher trainings have been conducted.

The Gambia is working with neighboring countries, especially Senegal, to coordinate surveillance and enhance monitoring at entry points.

Public information campaigns have been launched, with ongoing efforts by the Directorate of Health Promotion and Education to strengthen risk communication and community engagement for awareness and early reporting.

Preparations for vaccine deployment are underway in collaboration with the EPI. The Mpox Vaccine Deployment Plan is being finalized, and regulatory approval is being sought from the Medicines Control Agency (MCA).
reports.other_sources: Ministry of Health, The Gambia

event_details.name: VNM: Other - 07-2025 - Typhoon Wipha-Heavy rain and flash flood

reports.summary: VNM: Flood - 07-2025 - Typhoon Wipha-flash flood #2 (2025-07-23)
reports.description:
As of 22 July 2025, Typhoon Wipha weakened into a tropical depression over northern Viet Nam and later into a low-pressure system along the Viet Nam–Lao border. Despite weakening, the storm brought widespread heavy rainfall, flash floods, and significant agricultural and housing damage, particularly in Thanh Hoa, Nghe An, Phu Tho, Ninh Binh, and Hung Yen provinces.

Initial reports indicate one person missing and another injured due to flash floods in Nghe An. Over 400 houses were damaged, and more than 119,000 hectares of rice fields were flooded. Local authorities are actively operating pumps to prevent waterlogging. The storm also caused the loss of livestock and disrupted daily life in multiple provinces.

In Nghe An Province, extreme rainfall led to record-breaking flood levels along the Ca River. At several hydrological stations, water levels exceeded Alert Level 3 and surpassed historical flood records. The Ban Ve hydropower reservoir also recorded inflows well above its design capacity, raising the risk of downstream flooding, flash floods, and landslides. Authorities remain on high alert as water levels continue to rise in mid- and downstream areas.
reports.title: Typhoon Wipha-flash flood
reports.actions_others: On the morning of 22 July, as Typhoon No. 3 (Wipha) made landfall along the coastal areas of Hung Yen and Ninh Binh provinces, Deputy Prime Minister Trần Hồng Hà led a central government delegation to Thanh Hoa province to inspect key storm prevention and response sites. These included the anti-erosion embankment at Van Ha Bridge, the Ngoc Quang sluice in Xuan Lap Commune, and the Cua Dat irrigation reservoir. Relevant ministries mobilized resources to support local response efforts, enhanced forecasting for the Ca River basin, and worked to ensure transport safety and address landslide risks. The Viet Nam Red Cross Society (VNRC) continued to coordinate with authorities and monitor the situation. At this time, no international support is required. This serves as the final update on Typhoon Wipha’s landfall in Viet Nam.
reports.other_sources:
Viet Nam Disaster Management Authority (VDMA)
Tuoi Tre News

event_details.name: LAO: Flood - 07-2025 - Heavy Rains and Flash Floods

reports.summary: LAO: Flood - 07-2025 - Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Wipha #3 (2025-07-23)
reports.description:
Tropical Storm Wipha, which entered Lao PDR on 21 July and has since weakened into a low-pressure system, has triggered widespread flooding and severe weather across multiple provinces. Heavy rainfall, compounded by water releases from several hydropower dams, has led to flash floods, landslides, and infrastructure damage—particularly in Xieng Khouang, Xaysomboun, Xayabouly, Vientiane, Khammuane, and Bolikhamxay.

Severe flooding has impacted numerous districts, with reports of bridge collapses, power outages, and isolated communities. In Luang Prabang, the Khan River rose rapidly, while two bridges collapsed in Thathom district (Xaysomboun). Damages in Ngern district (Xayabouly) alone are estimated at LAK 16.7 billion (approx. USD 835,000). Authorities have launched emergency responses, including power shutdowns in Vang Vieng and Kasi districts, and temporary suspension of train services along the Laos-China Railway. Residents in flood-prone and mountainous areas have been urged to stay alert as the system continues to bring heavy rain and flash flood risks.

actions_taken.summary:
The Lao Red Cross headquarters coordinated nationwide preparedness and response efforts by issuing alerts to provincial branches to monitor weather updates, liaise with local disaster management committees, and prepare for rapid response. 

The LRC leadership tasked its headquarter with continuous coordination, data collection, and reporting from affected areas, while also engaging with national partners, including the National Disaster Management Committee, IFRC, and the Swiss Red Cross.

At the provincial level, LRC branches mobilized relief supplies from local warehouses and coordinated closely with authorities to support evacuations using Red Cross boats and rescue vehicles. Water treatment units were deployed to provide clean drinking water to displaced communities, including over 600 people in Naphai Village, Nan District.

Provincial branches in Luang Prabang, Xiengkhouang, and Huaphan distributed household essentials, food, and clothing to more than 1,900 people across multiple villages, with total relief assistance valued at over 158 million kip. Provincial teams also maintained regular reporting to headquarters to inform ongoing coordination and response.

reports.title: Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Wipha
reports.summary: LAO: Flood - 07-2025 - Heavy rain from Tropical Storm Wipha #4 (2025-08-04)
reports.description:
According to local government, intense rainfall from Tropical Depression Wipha caused widespread flooding and landslides across northern and central Lao PDR, affecting 46 districts and over 571 villages, with four people dead, seven missing, and thousands displaced. Khammouane Province was the most affected, with severe flooding in Hinboun District impacting over 335 families and causing extensive damage to homes, farmland, and infrastructure. 

A total of 14 provinces across Lao PDR were affected by monsoon floods and landslides, with nine of them—Vientiane Province, Bolikhamxay, Luang Prabang, Xayaboury, Xieng Khouang, Huaphan, Xaysomboun, Khammouane, and Bokeo—directly impacted by Tropical Depression Wipha.

Authorities have issued warnings as Mekong River levels continue to rise, particularly in Vientiane Capital and Pakse.
reports.other_sources:
United Nations Lao PDR: 2025 Lao PDR Monsoon Situation Report 5 (31 July)
Lao Red Cross
reports.actions_others:
Governments
•	The Central Disaster Management Committee is planning a rapid needs assessment in five northern provinces: Vientiane Province, Luang Prabang, Xayaboury, Xieng Khouang, and Huaphan.
•	In Khammouane Province, local authorities held a coordination meeting to direct emergency assistance and recovery efforts in flood-affected Natan area.
•	Military personnel and local authorities have been deployed in multiple provinces—including Vientiane, Xayaboury, Xieng Khouang, and Luang Prabang—to support evacuations and assist flood-affected communities.
•	 In Bokeo Province, police, village authorities, and residents cleaned the Ban Mee Phoukha temple grounds after flooding left debris in the courtyard.
•	 The Houaphan Provincial Health Office delivered emergency supplies worth over 27 million kip to Kuan District.
•	In Xieng Khouang Province, disaster committees provided initial assistance of 140 million kip and allocated 80 million kip for monitoring efforts in Xieng Nguen and Nan districts.
•	The Central Disaster Management Committee launched a national fundraising campaign on 30 July, calling on all sectors to contribute funds or essential goods to support flood recovery.

actions_taken.summary:
In Nghe An, over 6,000 households (approx. 24,000–26,000 people) have received support through cash assistance, household kits, clean water supplies, food items, and community kitchens. Priority was given to families whose houses were damaged, swept away, or whose livelihoods were heavily impacted.

In Dien Bien, VNRC supported around 60 households (approx. 250–300 people) affected by landslides and erosion, including families who lost members or whose homes were destroyed. Assistance included funeral support, cash grants, and house repair/reconstruction support.

The total estimated value of VNRC support to date is approximately VND 5.1 billion ~ CHF 158.100
IFRC CCD Office is working closely with the VNRC and its focal staff to provide any technical assistance if required. Situation is continuously monitored.

event_details.name: VNM: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2025 - Viet Nam - Pluvial/Flash Flood - 08/2025

reports.title: Viet Nam - Pluvial/Flash Flood - 08/2025
reports.summary: VNM: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2025 - Viet Nam - Pluvial/Flash Flood - 08/2025
reports.description:
Between late July and early August 2025, prolonged heavy rainfall associated with Storm Wipha triggered widespread flooding, flash floods, and landslides across three northern provinces of Viet Nam: Nghệ An, Điện Biên, and Sơn La. The most severely affected areas are remote mountainous communes where rainfall exceeded seasonal norms and overwhelmed already fragile infrastructure. As a result, at least 19 people have died, one is missing, and over 11 others injured. More than 2,000 houses were either damaged or destroyed, while major roads and bridges were washed away, isolating dozens of communities.

Approximately 76,600 to 85,600 people have been directly affected, including thousands who lost homes, access to clean water, food sources, and means of livelihood. In Nghệ An alone, over 58,000 people across 132 villages in 15 communes have been cut off due to road blockages and rising river levels. In Điện Biên and Sơn La, many families were forced to evacuate or take shelter in temporary locations as flash floods inundated homes and farmland. Livelihoods have been heavily disrupted, with thousands of hectares of rice, crops, and livestock lost. Immediate humanitarian needs include shelter, food, safe water, and access to healthcare for displaced and isolated households.
reports.other_sources:
Viet Nam Disaster Management Authority
Viet Nam Red Cross
Vnexpree
reports.actions_others:
In response, the Prime Minister issued an urgent directive (No. 125/CĐ-TTg) calling for immediate recovery actions. On 2 August, the Government approved an emergency fund of VND 250 billion (USD ~10 million) from the central contingency budget to support the three hardest-hit provinces — Điện Biên (VND 100 billion), Nghệ An (VND 100 billion), and Sơn La (VND 50 billion).

Affected populations continue to face high risks of food insecurity, waterborne diseases, and psychological distress due to the loss of homes, livelihoods, and access to basic services. Priorities remain on life-saving support, restoring access, and stabilizing living conditions for displaced and vulnerable households.

The Chilean Red Cross, through the teams on the ground, has identified needs for RCF, first aid, SMAP, dissemination of information and support in the evacuation of the elderly.

That is why local, regional and national authorities have communicated at different levels to manage and support prioritized sectors in shelters or safe zones established within the territory.

Tsunami amplitudes recorded by sea level stations:

The tsunami threat level indicated in bulletin 28 issued by SHOA is maintained. The amplitudes recorded by the sea level stations are as follows:

SENAPRED at 07:25 a.m. on July 30, declared a Red Alert for tsunami for the communes of the continental coastal border between the regions of Arica and Parinacota and Magallanes, including the Insular and Antarctic territory, in force since July 29, 2025.

Meanwhile, at 10:30 p.m. yesterday, the National Disaster Risk Management Committee (COGRID) was convened, and at 7:00 a.m. today an Evaluation Meeting, in order to establish the coordinations and courses of action. In the same way, the Regional Directorates convened their respective Regional COGRIDs.

The evacuation processes have been carried out in an orderly manner. Additionally, shelters have been set up in some communes if necessary. On the other hand, the Ministry of Education suspended classes for all educational establishments, located on the coastal edge between the regions of Arica and Parinacota and Los Lagos, for today, Wednesday, July 30.

The Chilean Navy instructed that all vessels present at sea must remain in a 200-meter-deep shelter zone. Meanwhile, smaller vessels that cannot go out into deep waters must remain moored and anchored to the port.

The evacuation process will be supported by public security from Municipalities, Armed Forces, Firefighters, Carabineros and PDI distributing their personnel at strategic and required points.

Likewise, the evacuation process will be reinforced with the sending of SAE messaging for Tsunami Warning, Precautionary Status or Cancellation, as appropriate.

Finally, the response teams of the Disaster Prevention and Response System (SINAPRED) are deployed on the ground and evaluating the emergency situations derived from this event.

 

Evacuation processes

Concepción: Due to the threat of tsunami flooding in the area, authorities began the preventive evacuation of the local jail, transferring inmates to prisons in Concepción. At the same time, the hospital – also located in a flood zone – is evaluating alternatives for the transfer of patients and the protection of essential equipment and supplies.

 

Critical Infrastructure

Between the regions of Arica and Parinacota and Los Lagos, 5 prisons are reported to be below level 30, which are being evacuated. 33 health facilities in the regions of Tarapacá, Antofagasta, Coquimbo, Valparaíso, O'Higgins, Maule, Biobío, La Araucanía, Los Ríos and Los Lagos that are in the flood zone were evacuated (308 patients in total). Similarly, the immunobiological deposits (vaccines and immunoglobulin) of the communes of Lebu and Talcahuano in the Biobío Region were transferred to a safe zone. 

 

Operations are paralyzed in all ports from the Arica Region to the San Antonio Region; and without ships in Talcahuano.

reports.other_sources: SENAPRED
reports.actions_others:
According to the information provided by the national authorities, 1.5 million people have evacuated from the coastal zone, which is estimated to be 70% of the population in the flood zone due to tsunami risk, with preliminary information an evacuation in large numbers of people from the coastal zone is expected at quota 30 as established in the safety and evacuation zones,  the information required for safe evacuation has been reinforced through the SAE communication and messaging channels. 

Through the Regional Risk Management Directors, relevant information has been collected for a safe evacuation by the population, and the needs to keep the population informed regarding the arrival times of the waves to the coastal sector. 

Maritime authorities have been deployed in the coastal sectors in addition to intensifying the support of the police in the territory, together with the activation of the regional COGRIDs that are providing information to the institutions that are part of the civil protection system.

actions_taken.summary:
En cumplimiento con los Principios Fundamentales que la rigen, su misión humanitaria y 
el rol de auxiliaridad, la Cruz Roja Guatemalteca ha realizado acciones de respuesta ante 
este evento, para lo cual se mantiene un monitoreo constante de la situación, así como la 
coordinación con las autoridades de país. 
Para ello, se movilizó a un equipo de intervención en respuesta hacia el departamento de 
Jutiapa, conformado por 13 personas e integrado por médicos, psicólogos, técnicos de 
salud y agua y saneamiento, enfermería y coordinación, a fin de brindar atención a la 
población más afectada en los municipios de ese departamento.

En redes sociales, la CRG promociona las medidas de prevención enfocadas en la 
elaboración del plan familiar de emergencia y la mochila de las 72 horas. 
Se establece una coordinación directa y permanente con el Centro de Operaciones de 
Emergencia de Conred y el Ministerio de Salud Pública, para coordinar los requerimientos 
de las instituciones gubernamentales y la implementación del rol auxiliar. 
Enlace para fotografías y videos de la operación de Cruz Roja Guatemalteca, disponible 
en: https://x.com/CruzRojaGT_

event_details.name: GTM: Earthquake - 07-2025 - Sensitive Earthquakes in Guatemala

reports.title: Actividad Sísmica Jutiapa Guatemala 2025
reports.summary: GTM: Earthquake - 07-2025 - Actividad Sísmica Jutiapa Guatemala 2025 #2 (2025-08-01)
reports.description:
A partir de las 15:21 horas del 29 de julio del 2025 se inició la secuencia sísmica localizada

en Jutiapa con dos sismos de magnitud local de 5.8 y 5.7, registrándose, hasta la fecha de

la emisión de este informe, 482 eventos sísmicos, los cuales son pertenecientes a esta

secuencia sísmica; de estos, 52 han sido reportados sensibles por la población, de acuerdo

a la información proporcionada por Instituto Nacional de Sismología, Vulcanología,

Meteorología e Hidrología de Guatemala – Insivumeh1

.

De acuerdo a la Conred, los eventos se registraron también en los departamentos de

Escuintla, Jutiapa, Jalapa y Santa Rosa2

.

Hasta la fecha, como consecuencia de estos sismos, se ha realizado la evacuación de más

de 1,000 personas, de las cuales 739 se encuentran albergadas en los centros habilitados

por el Sistema CONRED 3

.

Las estadísticas preliminares indican que hay más de 77 emergencias reportadas, 2,038

personas afectadas por este evento, 1,998 evacuadas, 1,262 albergadas y al menos, 26

personas heridas que se encuentran hospitalizadas. También, 2 personas fallecieron como

consecuencia directa de estos sismos.

En cuanto a daños de infraestructura, hay reportes de 2 escuelas afectadas. En cuanto a

viviendas, 99 se registran con daño leve, 249 con daño moderado y 161 con daño severo.
reports.other_sources: Sismicede Conred
reports.actions_others:
En respuesta a este evento, la Secretaría Ejecutiva de la CONRED ha desplegado equipos 
de respuesta y personal técnico hacia el departamento de Jutiapa para realizar 
Evaluaciones Rápidas de Daños en Vivienda (ERDV) en comunidades donde se reportó 
sensibilidad sísmica o posibles afectaciones. 
Las instituciones de socorro realizaron el traslado de personas heridas hacia el Hospital 
Nacional de Jutiapa, donde están siendo atendidas. 
Se han habilitado al menos, 6 albergues en el área para brindar atención a las personas 
afectadas4
. 
A través de los diferentes medios de comunicación, las autoridades han emitido 
recomendaciones dirigidas a la población para indicar las acciones a realizar ante la 
continuidad de sismos, a fin de preservar la vida y la salud. Estos mensajes se enfocan en 
la elaboración del plan familiar de respuesta, la mochila de las 72 horas y los números de 
emergencia de los cuerpos de socorro.

According to what was reported by the General Directorate of Water (DGA), through its online reporting system of the stations of the Fluviometric Network, it is indicated that the station of the "Trancura River before the Llafenco River", is at the yellow alert threshold, which, if the flow continues to increase, could affect people and damage the commune's infrastructure.

reports.actions_others:
The Regional Directorates of SENAPRED maintain continuous monitoring in each of the communes in coordination with the National System for Disaster Prevention and Response (SINAPRED), based on their coordination procedures at the regional level.

At the moment, 2 technical tables have been held at the national level and various technical tables and COGRID at the Regional, Provincial and Communal levels.

event_details.name: KGZ: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2025 - Issyk-Kul

reports.title: Issyk-Kul
reports.summary: KGZ: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2025 - Issyk-Kul
reports.description:
According to the storm warning of Kyrgyzhydromet under the Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic, in the period from July 28 to 31, 2025 in the regions of the country were expected floods caused by heavy rains, so on July 30, 2025 at about 23:00 in the village of Tamchy Toru-Aigyr-Tamchy village of Toru-Aigyr-Tamchy aiyl aimak of Issyk-Kul district, as a result of heavy rains there were mudflows.

The neighboring village of Kosh-Kol also experienced intense precipitation leading to localized floods
